Timestamps. 
00:00 - Introduction
00:45 - Core Concepts of Buying Options
    - Introduction to three key concepts: Days to Expiration (DTE), Delta, and Gamma
01:31 - Days to Expiration (DTE)
    - Explanation of how the length of time until expiration affects option price and behavior
    - Longer time frames mean more expensive options due to extrinsic value
    - Slower Gamma movement in out-of-the-money options with longer expiration
04:01 - Delta
    - Understanding Delta: Measures rate of change of an optionâ€™s premium per $1 move in the underlying asset
    - Higher Delta means more expensive options but better responsiveness to price changes
    - Delta and Gamma relationship and their impact on in-the-money and out-of-the-money options
06:01 - Gamma
    - Introduction to Gamma: Rate of change of Delta
    - Gamma is higher in at-the-money options and as expiration approaches
    - Impact of Gamma on potential profit from options with high Delta closer to expiration
09:31 - Practical Application and Platform Demonstration
    - Demonstration using GameStop options to illustrate discussed concepts
    - Practical examples of selecting options based on DTE, Delta, and Gamma
    - Examination of 60 Delta call options and their behavior over different expiration periods
12:00 - Advanced Considerations
    - Further exploration of strategic considerations in options trading
    - Benefits and trade-offs of higher Delta options
    - Scenarios demonstrating the impact of Delta and Gamma on option profitability
15:01 - Summary and Best Practices
    - Summary of key points to consider when buying options
    - Importance of balancing Delta, Gamma, and DTE
    - Practical tips for minimizing losses and optimizing trades

14:00 - Portfolio Visualizer Tool

   - Comparing different portfolio strategies

16:00 - Investing for the Long Term
   - Importance of consistent saving and investing
   - Potential outcomes of long-term investing

18:00 - Trading vs. Investing
   - Differences in approach between trading and investing
   - Need for a trading plan for active traders

19:30 - Conclusion
   - Encouragement to start investing and embrace delayed gratification
   - Invitation for questions and further discussion

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Discussing common trading mistakes

01:00 - Mistake 1: Low Barrier to Entry
   - Trading appears easy but is difficult
   - Importance of acknowledging the skill gap

02:00 - Mistake 2: Lack of Structured Learning
   - Trading without a structured learning path
   - Recommendation: Create a learning plan

03:00 - Mistake 3: Complexity of Markets
   - Markets are highly complex with innumerable inputs
   - Need for a trading plan and log

04:00 - Mistake 4: Money Making Mechanisms
   - Understanding how money is made in the market
   - Different strategies and their applications

05:00 - Mistake 5: Starting with a Small Account
   - Challenges of trading with a small account
   - Limitations and unrealistic expectations

06:00 - Mistake 6: Overconfidence with Short Experience
   - Misconceptions about early success
   - Importance of experiencing different market conditions

08:00 - Mistake 7: Dunning-Kruger Effect
   - Overestimating proficiency early on
   - Recognizing the learning curve in trading

09:00 - Mistake 8: Looking for Reasons to Say No
   - Focusing on the best opportunities
   - Strong convictions loosely held

10:00 - Mistake 9: Avoiding Responsibility
   - Importance of taking ownership of trades
   - Speculative trades and accountability

11:00 - Mistake 10: Identifying as a Specific Type of Trader
   - Being flexible in trading strategies
   - Adapting to market conditions

12:00 - Mistake 11: Common Losing Habits
   - Disposition effect and naive reinforcement
   - Understanding common pitfalls

13:00 - Mistake 12: Beating the Market in Different Ways
   - Different approaches to outperforming the market
   - Importance of managing drawdowns

14:00 - Mistake 13: Abolishing Normal Thought Patterns
   - Avoiding bargain hunting in the market
   - Examples of market misconceptions

15:00 - Mistake 14: Avoiding Simple Explanations
   - Recognizing the complexity of markets
   - Importance of focusing on price movement

17:00 - Conclusion
   - Summary of key points
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and further discussion

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Understanding good vs. bad risk in trading

01:00 - Making Money in the Markets
   - Risk-free rate vs. taking risk
   - Different ways to take on risk in trading

02:00 - Understanding Personal Risk Profile
   - Identifying risk aversion and risk openness
   - Balancing risk and reward in trading

03:00 - Bad Risk: Undefined Risk
   - Importance of defining risk in trades
   - Example: Using a stop-loss in undefined risk trades

04:30 - Bad Risk: Unknown Risk
   - Identifying and managing unknown risks
   - Example: Checking for earnings announcements

06:00 - Bad Risk: Misunderstood Risk
   - Understanding true risk in trade structures
   - Example: Comparing vertical spreads to naked puts

07:30 - Good Risk: Defined Risk
   - Importance of clearly defined risk
   - Analyzing risk vs. profit potential

08:30 - Good Risk: Researched Risk
   - Importance of researching potential risks
   - Example: Checking for market events and news

09:30 - Good Risk: Accepted Risk
   - Understanding and accepting risk in broader systems
   - Example: Risk in earnings plays

10:30 - Asymmetric Return Profiles
   - Creating trades with asymmetric return profiles
   - Example: VIX ratio call diagonal trade

12:00 - Best Practices for Managing Risk
   - Defining risk in every trade
   - Researching potential risks and assessing risk-reward profiles

13:00 - Conclusion
   - Summary of key points
   - Encouragement to evaluate risk and reward carefully
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and questions

Tom Sosnoff
FOUNDER & CEO, TASTYLIVE

Tom Sosnoff is a trailblazer in the online brokerage industry, driving innovation and financial education for investors of all levels. He offers up his expertise in the options markets as co-host of tastylive LIVE!, airing daily on the tastylive network.

A former floor trader, Tom became one of Chicago's most well-known serial entrepreneurs in fintech when he built a breakthrough options-trading platform, thinkorswim, later sold to TD-Ameritrade for $750 million.

Leveraging over 20 years of experience as a Market Maker for the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) and one of the original OEX traders in the S&P 100 Index pit, Tom pursued his vision to educate retail investors in options trading and build a superior trading platform and a brokerage firm that specialized in options. With that vision in mind, tastylive was founded in 2011. Six years later, tastytrade launched with Scott Sheridan at the helm as CEO.

   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Sharing six lessons learned from 16 years of trading

   - Markets are indifferent to individual traders
   - Understanding and adapting to market conditions

03:00 - Lesson 2: Small Accounts Face Disadvantages
   - Challenges of trading with a small account
   - Importance of saving and adapting strategies

06:00 - Lesson 3: Smart Ideas Mean Nothing Without Application
   - Balance between theoretical understanding and practical application
   - Importance of practical experience in trading

08:00 - Lesson 4: Removing Ego and Emphasizing Process
   - Difference between prediction and forecast
   - Importance of maintaining an iterative process

11:00 - Lesson 5: Ignore Noise and Focus on Your Own Analysis
   - Importance of being autonomous and not relying on others
   - Gathering information without being influenced by noise

14:00 - Lesson 6: Adding Structure and Organization
   - Importance of having a trading plan and log
   - Using scientific methods to test and refine strategies

17:00 - Conclusion
   - Recap of key points
   - Encouragement to be an outlier and focus on structure and process

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Developing a trade management plan

01:00 - Importance of a Trade Management Plan
   - Avoiding unexpected outcomes
   - Introduction to the nine key questions to ask before placing a trade

02:00 - Practical Examples from Reddit
   - Examples of traders lacking a plan
   - Importance of having a plan before entering a trade

03:30 - Concept of Trade Management Flow
   - Generalized and strategy-specific trade management plans
   - Importance of a repeatable and efficient system

05:00 - Thought Exercise in Trade Management
   - Preemptively thinking through potential scenarios
   - Marine Corps planning process as an analogy

06:00 - Informative Nature of Trade Management
   - Creating a feedback loop for long-term trading success
   - Optimizing strategies based on tracked results

07:00 - Detailed Trade Flow
   - Steps involved in trade management flow
   - Defining total allocation, initial outlay, and scaling rules

09:00 - Nine Key Questions to Ask Before Placing a Trade
   - How much capital does this position get?
   - What is the initial outlay?
   - How do you scale in and out?
   - How can I get hurt holding this?
   - What is the maximum risk and how will you manage it?
   - How do we know if we are right?
   - How do we know if we are wrong?
   - How will you manage profits and losses?
   - What metrics are important for me to track?

12:00 - Example Application
   - Applying the nine questions to a hypothetical Garmin call trade
   - Defining stops, scaling, and managing risk

14:00 - Strategy-Specific Considerations
   - Adjusting the plan based on the specific strategy
   - Importance of defining details ahead of time

15:00 - Homework for Traders
   - Encouragement to use the nine questions before every trade
   - Balance between thoroughness and simplicity in planning

17:00 - Conclusion
   - Recap of key points
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and questions

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: How to start trading without the BS

01:00 - Motivations
   - Making money as the primary goal
   - Different financial goals for different traders

02:00 - Landscape of Trading
   - Retail traders vs. institutions
   - Understanding the competitive nature of trading

03:30 - Common Mistakes
   - High failure rate among traders
   - Importance of understanding the difficulty of trading

05:00 - Defining Objectives
   - Importance of having clear objectives
   - Example objectives: developing skill set, avoiding drawdowns

07:00 - Personal Background and Motivation
   - Personal story of financial struggles and motivation
   - The importance of saving and planning for the future

09:00 - Compound Growth Example
   - Example of the power of compound growth
   - Importance of aggressive saving and investing early

11:00 - Creating a Timeline
   - Suggested timeline for new traders
   - Year-by-year goals from paper trading to outperforming the market

13:00 - Trading Plan and Log
   - Importance of creating and maintaining a trading plan and log
   - Continuous improvement through documentation and analysis

15:00 - Start Putting Money to Work
   - Investing in the S&P 500 while learning to trade
   - Reducing psychological pressure by having money invested

17:00 - Importance of Paper Trading
   - Benefits of paper trading for the first year
   - Addressing common criticisms of paper trading

19:00 - Summary and Final Thoughts
   - Key steps to start trading: define objectives, create a timeline, start a trading plan
   - Emphasis on aggressive saving and committing to the process
   - Encouragement to become a statistical outlier by putting in the necessary work

#trading #stockmarket #optionstrading

00:00 - Introduction
   - Overview of the video
   - Purpose: Systematic technical analysis, part two

01:00 - Starting with the Portfolio
   - Understanding the origin of the trade
   - Need vs. opportunity in the portfolio

03:00 - Orientation Phase
   - Big picture analysis
   - Economic conditions and market behavior

05:00 - Sector Analysis
   - Finding strength within sectors
   - Importance of a confluence of evidence

07:00 - Example Analysis with IWM
   - Applying different time frames for analysis
   - Determining if it's the right time for a trade

09:00 - Trend and Strength Analysis
   - Using various tools and time frames
   - Identifying bullish or bearish trends

11:00 - Long-term vs. Short-term Positions
   - Differentiating analysis based on time horizon
   - Value zones and long-term trends

13:00 - Precision Hypothesis
   - Matching strategy to the hypothesis
   - Example: VIX ratio call diagonal

15:00 - Setting P&L Targets
   - Using charts to set loss and profit targets
   - Adapting the plan based on market behavior

17:00 - Best Practices
   - Less is more in technical analysis
   - No magic indicators; focus on simplicity

19:00 - Probabilistic Outcomes
   - Using technical analysis for probabilistic understanding
   - Product quirks and catalysts

21:00 - Guard Rails and Scaling
   - Setting P&L targets and scaling positions
   - Importance of P&L validation and weighting indicators

23:00 - Conclusion
   - Recap of key points
   - Encouragement to apply systematic analysis
   - Invitation for viewer feedback and questions

#trading #stockmarket #tomsosnoff

Tom Sosnoff
FOUNDER & CEO, TASTYLIVE

Tom Sosnoff is a trailblazer in the online brokerage industry, driving innovation and financial education for investors of all levels. He offers up his expertise in the options markets as co-host of tastylive LIVE!, airing daily on the tastylive network.

A former floor trader, Tom became one of Chicago's most well-known serial entrepreneurs in fintech when he built a breakthrough options-trading platform, thinkorswim, later sold to TD-Ameritrade for $750 million.

Leveraging over 20 years of experience as a Market Maker for the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE) and one of the original OEX traders in the S&P 100 Index pit, Tom pursued his vision to educate retail investors in options trading and build a superior trading platform and a brokerage firm that specialized in options. With that vision in mind, tastylive was founded in 2011. Six years later, tastytrade launched with Scott Sheridan at the helm as CEO.

#Trading #Stocks #BeAnOutlier

The stock market is a great tool in our approach to developing wealth. I started investing at 16 and have been actively trading for 15+ years. I don't come from money and am nothing special - yet I still made my first million before I was 30. 

I share my approach to trading and wealth development without the BS. I cover things like investing basics, options trading, portfolio management, trading psychology, real estate and angel investing, and my first hand experience in creating wealth. I regularly provide updates on the markets and my trades as well as host guests that share their respective perspectives and expertise. Welcome to the Outliers!

I am not a financial advisor. All content is shared for educational and entertainment purposes only.
